proof:
Proof. Also by union bound and Markov inequality applied to Lemma 31, whp $G$ is such that for each $1 \le s \le n$ there are at most $n^{5/2}(ed)^s$ connected subsets of size $s$. By Lemmas 47 and 35, there is $A > 0$ such that for all $d$ large enough, whp $G$ is such that for all $\beta \in (0, \beta_1]$, any polymer $\gamma$ with at least $\frac{A \log n}{d}$ vertices has weight at most $q^{1-|V_G(\gamma)|/10}$, and also for any connected vertex set $S \subseteq V_C$ of size at least $\frac{A \log n}{d}$ has $e_G(S) \le (2d/3+1)|S|$. Further on, assume $G$ is such that the above holds. By the previous lemma and by union bound, it is sufficient to prove that
$$ \sum_{\substack{\gamma \in \cup_{F \in \Omega_C^{\mathrm{dis}}} \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}} \\ |V_G(\gamma)| \ge A \log n/d}} w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) \le q^{-A \log n/(25d)}. $$
For any connected subset $S$ of the size $\ge \frac{A \log n}{d}$, $e_G(S) \le (2d/3+1)|S|$, hence there are at most $2^{(2d/3+1)|S|}$ possible connected subgraphs of $G$ with the vertex set $S$. Hence the number of polymers with $s \ge \frac{A \log n}{d}$ vertices is at most $n^{5/2}(ed)^s 2^{(2d/3+1)s}$. By Lemma 47, for any polymer with $s \ge \frac{A \log n}{d}$ vertices, its weight is at most $q^{1-s/10}$. Thus summing through all possible sizes gives us that the the sum is at most
$$ \sum_{s \ge (A/d) \log n} n^{5/2}(ed)^s 2^{(2d/3+1)s} q^{1-s/10} = q n^{5/2} \sum_{s \ge (A/d) \log n} [2^{2d/3+1} ed q^{-1/10}]^s. $$
Finally, provided that $q$ is sufficiently large, $2^{2d/3+1}edq^{-1/10} < q^{-1/20}$, and for $q$ large enough, the sum can be also bound by $O(n^{5/2}q^{-A \log n/(20d)}) \le q^{-A \log n/(25d)}$.
